title: Armand de Waele
text:
Armand Michel A. de Waele (17 November 1887 – December 1966) was a <a href="British%20people">British</a> <a href="chemist">chemist</a>, noted for his contributions to <a href="rheology">rheology</a>, and after whom the <a href="Power-law%20fluid">Ostwald-de Waele</a> relationship for <a href="non-Newtonian%20fluid">non-Newtonian fluid</a>s is named.
De Waele was born in <a href="Islington">Islington</a>, <a href="London">London</a>, in 1887, the son of a <a href="Belgians">Belgian</a> father and <a href="French%20people">French</a> mother. He held <a href="dual%20nationality">dual nationality</a> until the age of 21, when he chose to be a British rather than Belgian. He obtained a <a href="BSc">BSc</a> from the <a href="University%20of%20Westminster">Regent Street Polytechnic</a> then worked in the <a href="paint">paint</a> and <a href="linoleum">linoleum</a> industries. , In 1914, the same year was conscripted into the <a href="Royal%20Flying%20Corps">Royal Flying Corps</a>. That same year, he married a Frenchwoman, Jeanne Thérèse Duvivier (1892–1971), in <a href="Staines">Staines</a>. They had two sons, John and Peter
After the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, he joined <a href="Gestetner">Gestetner</a> as Chief Research Chemist, where he remained till 1957 when he retired. During this period he published 30 papers on rheology and patents on duplicating as well as a book. He was a Fellow of the <a href="Royal%20Institute%20of%20Chemistry">Royal Institute of Chemistry</a> and of the <a href="Institute%20of%20Physics">Institute of Physics</a>.
He died in <a href="London%20Borough%20of%20Enfield">Enfield</a> in December 1966.
